questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and weakness. On evaluation, CBC reveals low hemoglobin and reduced reticulocyte count. His WBC and platelet count were normal. BM examination reveals selective reduction in the erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Red cell aplasia 

 

Explanation:

 

This patient's presentation is classic for red cell aplasia. Think about what's happening here - the patient has anemia (shown by fatigue, pallor, weakness, and low hemoglobin), but interestingly, only the red blood cell line is affected. The white cells and platelets are completely normal.

 

The hallmark of red cell aplasia is that there is a selective reduction in erythroid precursors. The reduced reticulocyte count is also important as it tell us that the bone marrow isn't even trying to compensate for the anemia

 

Red cell aplasia can happen for several reasons - parvovirus B19 infection, certain medications, autoimmune disorders, or sometimes associated with thymomas. 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Aplastic anaemia If this were aplastic anemia, our patient would be having pancytopenia (low counts across all cell types). Our patient's normal WBC and platelets immediately rule this out.
  • Option C: Iron deficiency anemia; in IDA, the body typically responds by pumping out more reticulocytes to try to compensate. Our patient has reduced Reticulocyte count ruling this out. 
  • Option D: Hemolytic anemia would show increased red cell precursors leading to high reticulocyte count.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question tests knowledge of the differential diagnosis of anemia based on bone marrow findings and cellular indices. Specifically, it assesses the ability to recognize the characteristic pattern of red cell aplasia: selective reduction of erythroid precursors with normal myeloid and megakaryocytic lines, accompanied by anemia and low reticulocyte count. The key distinguishing feature is the selective involvement of only the red cell line, differentiating it from other anemias that show different patterns of cell production or destruction.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

 

A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI).

 

 

Diarrhea is a condition characterized by a change in the frequency and consistency of stools, occurring more than 3 times a day. Dysentery is a type of diarrhea that is associated with the presence of blood in stools. If the condition subsides within 7 days, it is termed as acute diarrhea, whereas if it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is termed as persistent diarrhea.

 

Acute diarrhea is commonly caused by intestinal infections, with rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. coli being the major infectious agents. Other causes of acute diarrhea include certain drugs, food allergies, and systemic infections such as urinary tract infection and otitis media.

 

Assessing the degree of dehydration is the most important aspect of evaluating diarrhea. Dehydration can occur due to excessive loss of fluids and electrolytes through diarrhea, which can lead to serious complications. Therefore, it is important to identify and manage dehydration early on to prevent complications

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child with signs of lethargy, poor feeding, and slow skin pinch return should be classified as having severe dehydration and managed urgently as per IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of migration of neural crest cells

 

Hirschsprung disease is caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall.

 

Hirschsprung disease, also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon, occurs when the normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum is interrupted or the ganglion cells die prematurely. This results in a distal intestinal segment with neither the Meissner submucosal nor the Auerbach myenteric plexus ("aganglionosis"). Coordinated peristaltic contractions are absent, and functional obstruction occurs, resulting in proximal dilation.

 

The absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel leads to an inability to coordinate peristaltic contractions, resulting in functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation. This can lead to symptoms such as abdominal distension, constipation, and failure to pass meconium shortly after birth.

 

The diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is made based on a combination of clinical presentation, radiographic findings, and histologic examination of rectal biopsy specimens. Treatment typically involves surgical resection of the aganglionic segment of the bowel, followed by re-anastomosis or creation of a colostomy.

 

Complications of Hirschsprung disease include enterocolitis, fecal impaction, and even sepsis, so early diagnosis and prompt treatment are important to prevent these complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of ganglion cells: While the result of the disease is a bowel segment lacking ganglion cells, the primary cause is the failure of migration of neural crest cells rather than a secondary loss of ganglion cells.

 

Option C. Visceral myopathy: Visceral myopathy involves primary muscle pathology of the bowel, which is not the cause of Hirschsprung disease.

 

Option D. Obstruction by inflammatory stricture: Inflammatory strictures are not related to the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease, which is due to congenital aganglionosis rather than inflammation or stricture formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung disease is primarily caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall during embryonic development, resulting in aganglionosis in the distal bowel and leading to functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation.

questions.text:
Which are the tumor markers for the ultrasound image shown below? (NEET PG 2024)

 

 

 

  1. CA 125
  2. LDH
  3. AFP
  4. hCG
  5. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4,5


The ultrasound image shows an ovarian mass, and various tumor markers are used in the evaluation of ovarian tumors to help in diagnosis and management:

 

  1. CA 125: This is primarily used as a marker for epithelial ovarian cancer, especially serous cystadenocarcinoma. Elevated levels of CA 125 are often associated with advanced stages of the disease.
  2. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): This marker is associated with dysgerminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the ovary. Elevated LDH levels can suggest the presence of this tumor.
  3. AFP (Alpha-Fetoprotein): AFP is a marker used for yolk sac tumors, which are rare but aggressive ovarian germ cell tumors.
  4. hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): hCG is elevated in cases of non-gestational choriocarcinoma, which is another form of germ cell tumor.
  5. CA 19-9: This tumor marker is associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma, a type of ovarian epithelial tumor. It is also elevated in other gastrointestinal malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Different tumor markers, including CA 125, LDH, AFP, hCG, and CA 19-9, are utilized to assess ovarian masses and differentiate between various types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests a suspected urethral injury with blood at the urethral meatus, which is commonly caused by external trauma or instrumentation.
  •  To confirm urethral rupture, the next step would be an ascending urethrogram.
  • Ascending urethrogram: Correct. In a patient who is hemodynamically stable and without symptoms of a full bladder, retrograde urethrography will help determine the extent of the injury and decide on the next appropriate steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheterization: In the setting of suspected urethral injury, as evidenced by the presence of blood at the tip of the urethral meatus, inserting a Foley catheter can be harmful. It could potentially exacerbate the injury or convert a partial tear into a complete one. Hence, this is contraindicated without first confirming the integrity of the urethra.

 

Option C. Nephrogram: A nephrogram is an imaging study of the kidneys and their function. While it can give details about the upper urinary tract, it's not typically used for evaluating urethral injuries.

 

Option D. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy, or suprapubic catheter placement, involves inserting a catheter directly into the bladder through the abdominal wall. It's done to divert urine when urethral catheterization is not possible or contraindicated, such as in the setting of a known or suspected urethral injury. This will be attempted after an urethrogram confirms a rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Ehrlichia chaffeensis

questions.text: Image of Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ehrlichia chaffeensis

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is an obligate intracellular, Gram-negative species of Rickettsiales bacteria. It is a zoonotic pathogen transmitted to humans by the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum) and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME).

 

Ehrlichiosis is evidenced by the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions known as morulae in monocytes, which can be observed on a Giemsa-stained blood film.

 

Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Transmission: By the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum).
  • Symptoms: Patients typically exhibit symptoms within 1 to 2 weeks after tick infection. Early symptoms include fever, headache, malaise, low-back pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Some patients may also have myalgias, arthralgias, coughing, pharyngitis, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and changes in mental status.
  • Diagnosis: Besides observing morulae in monocytes, serological tests like indirect fluorescent antibody tests and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are also used for diagnosis.
  • Treatment: TOC Doxycycline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect. Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), typically associated with rash and vascular endothelial damage, not morulae in monocytes.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect. Rickettsia conorii causes Mediterranean spotted fever, which also does not present with morulae in monocytes.

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Incorrect. Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA), where morulae are found in granulocytes, not monocytes. The presence of morulae in granulocytes is characteristic of Anaplasma infection.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is identified by the presence of morulae in monocytes and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis. The proper treatment is doxycycline, and diagnosis is confirmed through blood smear, serological tests, and PCR.

 

GAME – Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kerion

 

  • The case of a young boy coming into contact with a zoophilic organism and displaying symptoms of a boggy inflammatory mass, accompanied by thick crusting and matting of hair, indicates a possible diagnosis of kerion.
  • Kerion is an intense inflammatory form of tinea capitis, caused by dermatophytes that have an affinity for animals (pet dog clue).

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms - T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount

 

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum à Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton à Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furuncle:

  • Description: Also known as a boil, a furuncle is a deep folliculitis, an infection of the hair follicle.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Furuncles are typically more localized and painful and would not be described as "boggy." Also, they don’t have a direct association with having a pet dog.

 

Option B. Epidermoid cyst:

  • Description: These are benign cysts originating from the epidermis. They are filled with keratin and have a characteristic central punctum as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Epidermoid cysts are typically non-painful unless infected. They do not usually present as boggy swellings and are not related to having a pet.

 

Option D. Folliculitis:

  • Description: Folliculitis is the inflammation or infection of one or more hair follicles.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Folliculitis on the scalp would typically present as multiple small, itchy, and red pustules. It wouldn't create a boggy swelling as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a fungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.

 

Reference: 

 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

choices.text: Hemophilia A
Hemophilia B
Von Willebrand disease

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is characterized by prolonged bleeding time due to a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a critical protein in platelet adhesion and aggregation processes. Prolonged APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) is also seen in this condition because VWF stabilizes factor VIII, an essential clotting factor. The deficiency or dysfunction of VWF thus impacts both primary hemostasis (bleeding time) and secondary hemostasis (APTT).

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Hemophilia A and B. Hemophilia B: These conditions involve deficiencies in clotting factors VIII and IX, respectively, which primarily affect the intrinsic coagulation pathway but not typically the bleeding time.

 

Option D. Hemophilia C: Known as a deficiency in factor XI, this condition also typically affects the intrinsic pathway and APTT but not bleeding time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolonged bleeding time and prolonged APTT is seen in Von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline
Continue the blood transfusion and perform an ECG
Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process
Administer corticosteroids and monitor vital signs

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a known history of thalassemia undergoes blood transfusion. Following the transfusion, she developed symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline

 

The patient's symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever after a blood transfusion suggest a possible transfusion reaction, which could be due to an ABO blood group incompatibility. In such cases, the immediate and appropriate step is to stop the blood transfusion immediately to prevent further complications. Pushing normal saline helps to dilute the mismatched blood and flush out the incompatible components from the patient's circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continuing the blood transfusion in the presence of these symptoms would be inappropriate and potentially harmful, as it could exacerbate the transfusion reaction.

 

Option C. While investigating for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process is important, it should be done after stopping the transfusion and stabilizing the patient's condition.

 

Option D. Administering corticosteroids may be helpful in managing severe transfusion reactions, but stopping the transfusion and pushing normal saline are the immediate and crucial steps to be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of suspected transfusion reactions, characterized by symptoms like anxiety, hypotension, and fever, the immediate action should be to stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Cushing's ulcers are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Head injury

 

Cushing's ulcers are specifically associated with head injuries or conditions that lead to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The mechanism involves vagal nerve stimulation due to the increased ICP, which in turn causes an overproduction of gastric acid leading to the development of ulcers. This is distinct from other types of stress-related gastric ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burns: This type of ulcer is known as Curling's ulcer, which occurs in response to severe burns and is related to the physiological stress and possible hypovolemia resulting from the burn injury, not the brain injury-related mechanism of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Option B. Stress: While stress can indeed lead to gastric ulcers, the specific term "Cushing's ulcers" is not used in this context. General stress-related ulcers do not typically involve the mechanism of vagal stimulation due to increased ICP.

 

Option D. Cell necrosis: This is a general process that can occur in many pathological conditions but does not specifically relate to the formation of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:


Cushing's ulcers are a specific type of peptic ulcer that occurs due to increased intracranial pressure resulting from head injuries. Recognizing this condition is important for managing patients with significant neurological trauma to prevent and treat these potentially serious gastrointestinal complications.

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

 

HS-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis.

 

Other investigations that can help include:

 

  • CSF examination
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

 

The image shows coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture in chick embryos: HSV-1 doesn’t grow well on Chick embryo line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.

 

Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.

 

Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  2. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  3. Cotrimoxazole is not given.
  4. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

It is true that bowel and bladder dysfunction increase the incidence of recurrence of UTI in children, and that children who experience a recurrence of UTI undergo a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: What is the vector for Orientia tsutsugamushi? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mite

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a disease endemic to the Asia-Pacific region. The vector for this pathogen is the larval stage of trombiculid mites, commonly known as chiggers. These mites transmit the bacteria to humans through their bite, typically occurring in areas with heavy vegetation and grassy fields where these mites are commonly found.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice are vectors for other diseases such as epidemic typhus (caused by Rickettsia prowazekii) but not for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Tick:  Ticks are vectors for diseases such as Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and tularemia but not for scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Flea - Fleas are vectors for diseases such as plague (caused by Yersinia pestis) and murine typhus (caused by Rickettsia typhi) but not for scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vector for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is the mite, specifically the larval stage known as chiggers.

choices.text: Child is delivered after death of biological father
Child is born to an unmarried couple
Child is abandoned by the parents

questions.text: A posthumous child can be best defined as: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Child is delivered after death of biological father

 

  • A posthumous child is defined as a child who is born after the death of one of their biological parents, typically the father. This term is most commonly used to describe children whose fathers passed away before they were born.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivery of a macerated fetus: A macerated fetus refers to a fetus that has died in utero and has undergone specific changes due to prolonged retention in the uterus.

 

Option C. Child is born to an unmarried couple: This describes the marital status of the parents and does not pertain to the death of a parent.

 

Option D. Child is abandoned by the parents: This refers to a situation where a child is left without care by their parents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of one of their biological parents, most commonly the father.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the emergency department with an unconscious state. An arterial blood analysis reveals the following values:
pH = 7.1; PCO2 = 22 mmHg; HCO3- = 16 mEq/l.

 

Identify the patient’s condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis

 

The patient’s arterial blood analysis shows a pH of 7.1, indicating an acidotic state (normal pH range: 7.35-7.45). The PCO2 is 22 mmHg, which is below the normal range (35-45 mmHg), and the HCO3- is 16 mEq/l, which is also below the normal range (22-28 mEq/l).

 

To determine whether the acidosis is metabolic or respiratory, we look at the bicarbonate (HCO3-) and PCO2 levels. In this case, the decreased HCO3- points towards a metabolic cause. The PCO2 is also low, indicating that the respiratory system is trying to compensate by reducing CO2 levels to counteract the acidosis. Therefore, the primary problem is metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition would present with an elevated pH (alkalosis) and usually high HCO3- levels, which is not consistent with the provided values.

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: This condition would present with an elevated PCO2 and a decreased pH. In this case, the PCO2 is low, not high, ruling out respiratory acidosis.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition would present with an elevated pH and a decreased PCO2. Although the PCO2 is low, the pH is also low, which is inconsistent with alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of metabolic acidosis, both the pH and bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels are decreased, and the respiratory system may compensate by lowering PCO2.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is released from zona fasciculata? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocorticoid

 

The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones, each responsible for producing different types of hormones. The mnemonic "GFR" can help remember the order and function of these zones:

 

  • Zona glomerulosa: Produces mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone), which are involved in regulating salt and water balance.
  • Zona fasciculata: Produces glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol), which play a key role in glucose metabolism, stress response, and immune function.
  • Zona reticularis: Produces androgens (e.g., dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione), which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

The zona fasciculata specifically secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which is involved in various physiological processes including metabolism, immune response, and stress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mineralocorticoid: This hormone is produced by the zona glomerulosa, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option C. Androgen: These hormones are produced by the zona reticularis, not the zona fasciculata.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: This hormone is produced by the adrenal medulla, not the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex is responsible for producing glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with symptoms that have persisted for five days, including high-grade fever, severe headache, generalized body aches, and a new cough accompanied by mild shortness of breath. She also reports noticing a blackish lesion at the site of an insect bite on her thigh after returning from a camping trip in a region known for chigger infestation. On physical examination, she is found to have a fever of 39°C, regional lymphadenopathy, and a well-defined eschar at the site of the lesion. Lung auscultation reveals mild diffuse rales. Laboratory tests show a normal white blood cell count and elevated liver enzymes. A chest X-ray indicates interstitial infiltrates, suggestive of atypical pneumonia that may be related to her primary infection. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intravenous doxycycline only.

 

The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with a rickettsial infection, likely contracted from a chigger bite, as evidenced by the eschar at the bite site, symptoms, and regional lymphadenopathy. The recommended treatment for rickettsial infections, such as scrub typhus, is doxycycline. This antibiotic is effective in treating the intracellular pathogens responsible for these infections. The additional symptoms of atypical pneumonia are also suggestive of a rickettsial etiology, which doxycycline can adequately address.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intravenous doxycycline and ceftriaxone: Combining doxycycline with ceftriaxone could be considered if there was a high suspicion of a secondary bacterial infection, particularly one that is serious and requires broad-spectrum coverage such as ceftriaxone. However, the patient's presentation does not strongly indicate such a co-infection.

 

Option C. Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin: This regimen is commonly used for community-acquired pneumonia with the intention to cover both typical and atypical pathogens. While the patient does exhibit signs of atypical pneumonia, the clinical findings are more suggestive of a rickettsial infection, which would not be optimally treated with this combination.

 

Option D. Intravenous doxycycline and azithromycin: Azithromycin could be added to doxycycline if there were concerns about atypical pneumonia due to pathogens like Mycoplasma pneumoniae or Chlamydophila pneumoniae. However, in the context of the patient's clinical presentation and recent exposure history, doxycycline alone should suffice to cover the likely rickettsial pathogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for rickettsial infections, such as those contracted from chigger bites, and is effective against both the primary infection and associated complications like atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following in IgA vasculitis warrants the use of corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GI bleeding

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, typically presents with symptoms such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash. These symptoms are often managed with supportive care and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, the use of corticosteroids is reserved for more severe manifestations of the disease.

 

GI bleeding: In cases where IgA vasculitis leads to gastrointestinal bleeding, corticosteroids are warranted. This is because GI bleeding indicates a severe form of the disease involving the gastrointestinal tract, which requires more aggressive treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arthritis: Joint pain and swelling associated with IgA vasculitis are usually mild and managed with NSAIDs or supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically indicated for arthritis alone in this context.

 

Option C. Abdominal pain: Abdominal pain in IgA vasculitis can often be managed with supportive care and NSAIDs. Corticosteroids are reserved for severe cases or when there is evidence of significant gastrointestinal involvement.

 

Option D. Skin rash: The characteristic purpuric rash of IgA vasculitis is usually self-limiting and does not require corticosteroids for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are indicated in IgA vasculitis primarily for severe manifestations such as gastrointestinal bleeding, indicating more extensive disease involvement. Other manifestations, such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash, are generally self-limiting and respond well to supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically required for these symptoms unless they are part of a more severe systemic involvement.

choices.text: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Anuj has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erythromycin only

 

In this case, the close contact of the patient is a 3-year-old child who had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, most likely as the 4th dose (1st booster). Therefore, only erythromycin is needed for prophylaxis.

 

It is crucial to monitor all household contacts for 7 days and obtain cultures from their nose and throat. Regardless of immunization status, all contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis such as benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One booster dose: This is not necessary because the child had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, which should still provide adequate immunity.

 

Option B. Nothing as the child is already exposed: This is incorrect because close contacts need to be managed to prevent the spread of diphtheria, and antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended.

 

Option C. Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid: This option is for those who have received less than three doses of diphtheria toxoid or have an unknown vaccination history. Since Ajay has been recently vaccinated, only erythromycin is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When Additional Toxoid is Needed:

  • <3 doses total received
  • >5 years since last dose
  • Unknown vaccination history
     

For a close contact of a diphtheria patient who has received the diphtheria vaccination within the last five years, antibiotic prophylaxis with erythromycin is the appropriate management step.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

 

OPTION B: Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic feature of alkaptonuria.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational objective:

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

  • MRI can cause movements of an intraocular foreign body (OFB) if it is magnetic and is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies.
  • The most common foreign bodies to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel.
  • Foreign bodies entering the eye may cause damage by mechanical effects, introduction of infection, or reacting with the intraocular tissues.
  • Localization of intraocular foreign body can be done through:
    1. Radiographic: Limbal ring method, which is the simplest but sparingly employed technique.
    2. Ultrasonographic: Can tell the position of even non-radio-opaque foreign bodies.
    3. CT scan: Presently the best method of intraocular foreign body localization, providing cross-sectional images with superior sensitivity and specificity than plain radiography and ultrasonography.

 

  • A foreign body should always be removed unless it is inert and probably sterile, little damage has been done to vision, or the process of removal will destroy sight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT: CT scan is highly effective for detecting and localizing metallic foreign bodies. It provides detailed cross-sectional images without the risks associated with MRI.

 

Option C. X-ray: X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies and is a safe initial imaging modality. However, it is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option D. B mode scan: B mode ultrasound can help localize non-radio-opaque foreign bodies and assess intraocular damage. It is safe and commonly used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

choices.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.
Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.
Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.
Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

 

  • The provided X-ray reveals a clearly defined exostosis, indicating a diagnosis of osteochondroma.
  • Additionally, the hyaline cap thickness of 2cms observed on the MRI raises concerns about the possibility of malignant transformation.

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is the developmental malformation thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap that is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs, a result of development malformation.
  • Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen which usually angle away from the growth plate.
  • Typically, the cap is only a few millimeters thick in adults, although it may be 2 cm thick in a child.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Osteochondromas are found on the metaphysis of a long bone near the physis.
  • They are seen most often on the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation.
  • Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; has enlarged further after skeletal maturity, there is loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma.
  • In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick. (Best evaluated by MRI).
  • Osteochondromas are of two types: Pedunculated and broad- based or sessile.
  • Pedunculated tumors are more common. The stalk is directed away from the physis adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the parent bone.
  • The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap
  • Treatment: 
    • Surgery (en bloc resection-extraperiosteal resection) is indicated for lesion that causes pain, symptomatic impingement on neurovascular structure, compromise of joint function, cosmetic deformity, painful bursa formation and rapid increase in size of lesion or when imaging features suggest malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint. This is not true for an osteochondroma. The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap which is irregular and usually grows away from the growth plate.

 

Option B. Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential. This is not true. The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma and 6% for patients with multiple hereditary exostoses. Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; any further enlargement after skeletal maturity takes place, loss of corticomedullary differentiation takes place. It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma. In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick which can be best evaluated by MRI).

 

Option C. Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone. This is not true. The stalk of the lesion grows away from the physis, adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the corresponding components of the parent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: A couple presents to the OPD with their 4-year-old child who has self-mutilating behavior and poor growth. Identify the condition and enzyme involved in it: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HGPRT deficiency

 

The child’s symptoms of self-mutilating behavior and poor growth are characteristic of Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. This is a rare inherited disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-Guanine Phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme is crucial in the purine salvage pathway, where it recycles purines into nucleotides rather than letting them degrade into uric acid.

 

When HGPRT is deficient, purines like hypoxanthine and guanine accumulate and are subsequently converted to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia and gout. The neurological manifestations, including self-mutilation and mental retardation, arise due to the deficiency in purine recycling, which is critical for proper brain function.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Xanthine oxidase is inhibited by allopurinol
  • The enzyme for salvage pathway is HGPRT

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogentisic Acid Oxidase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes Alkaptonuria, not Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. Alkaptonuria is characterized by dark urine, ochronosis, and arthritis, not self-mutilation or poor growth.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine Hydroxylase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by intellectual disability and a musty body odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine, but not self-mutilation or gout.

 

Option D. Benzoyl Acidase: This is not a relevant enzyme in this context, and its mention is incorrect or misleading.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is caused by a complete deficiency of HGPRT, leading to self-mutilation, poor growth, hyperuricemia, and gout.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

 

MCCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME

 

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bones involved)
  • Precocious puberty (endocrine abnormalities)
  • Cutaneous Pigmentation (café Au lait: coffee-colored spots)
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” bor- ders), as opposed to the smoothly marginated borders (“coast of California”) of the spots seen in neurofibromatosis.
  • Surgical treatment by curettage + bone grafting is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is the idiopathic destruction of histiocytes. The disease has characteristics of both an abnormal reactive process and a neoplastic process. It may present initially as a rash, and can disseminate and involve bone marrow, lungs, liver, spleen, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and the pituitary gland. Histologically, the primary lesion is granulomatous with an influx of eosinophils, macrophages, T cells and multinucleated cells. The Birbeck granule is the microscopic hallmark of the disorder but may not be seen in lesions of the spleen, liver, and GI tract. The rash may be distinguished by the presence of petechiae, bloody crusting, or firmly indurated nodules. Bony involvement occurs in 78% patients. Solitary osseous lesions are incidentally found and may include the skull, hip/pelvis, femur, or ribs. This bony involvement may produce bone pain. In long bones, endosteal scalloping may be responsible for a “budding appearance”.

 

 

Endosteal scalloping presenting as budding appearance

 

Option C. Neuroma with bone involvement. Morton's neuroma is one of the most common pain syndromes affecting the forefoot. It is characterized by tenderness and burning pain in the plantar surface of the forefoot, with painful paresthesias in the two affected toes. This pain syndrome is caused by perineural fibrosis of the interdigital nerves. Although the nerves between the third and fourth toes are affected most commonly, the second and third toes and, rarely, the fourth and fifth toes can be affected as well. Patients may feel like they are walking with a stone in the shoe. The pain worsens with prolonged standing or walking for long distances and is exacerbated by poorly fitting or improperly padded shoes. Morton's neuroma is associated with wearing tight, narrow-toed shoes. On physical examination, pain can be reproduced by firmly squeezing the 2 metatarsal heads together with one hand while placing firm pressure on the interdigital space with the other hand. This maneuver is known as the Mulder sign. The patient exhibits an antalgic gait in an effort to reduce weight bearing during walking.

 

 

Option D. Papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is an epithelial malignancy showing follicular cell differentiation and nuclear features. It is the most frequent thyroid neoplasm. The tumor usually appears as an irregular solid mass. One key feature is the ability to invade adjacent structures like lymphatics. About 10% patients may present with metastatic disease at initial presentation. It usually presents as an asymptomatic thyroid mass with or without enlargement of regional (cervical) lymph nodes. Hoarseness and dysphagia occur in approximately 20% cases, signaling recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement with vocal cord paralysis or tracheal compression. Nodal metastases in the lateral neck are reported in 27% patients. The examination reveals a painless hard lesion of less than 5 cm. The mass is often fixed and has irregular borders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots.
  • Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome.

questions.text:
Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Z line
  2. M line
  3. A band
  4. H zone
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,2

 

The proper order of bands within the sarcomere, moving from the periphery towards the center, is as follows: Z line - I band - A band - H zone - M line.

 

 

Z line: A dense protein structure that separates one sarcomere from the next and serves as an anchor for actin filaments.

 

I band: The light-colored region in a sarcomere composed of only thin actin filaments.

 

A band: The dark-colored region in a sarcomere containing both thick myosin and thin actin filaments.

 

H zone: The central part of the A band where only thick myosin filaments are present.

 

M line: The center of the sarcomere, providing structural support and anchoring the myosin filaments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of bands within the sarcomere, from the periphery towards the center, is Z line, A band, H zone, and M line.

choices.text: Substance P

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. VIP

 

Explanation

 

VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

 

During peristalsis, segment of intestine behind the bolus contracts while segment in front of it relaxes.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxes the segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which contracts the segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetylcholine: Incorrect as acetylcholine is involved in the contraction of the intestinal segment behind the bolus, not in the dilatation.

 

Option C. Substance P: Incorrect because it also contributes to the contraction of the intestinal muscles behind the bolus.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Incorrect as serotonin is involved in overall motility and secretion within the gut but not specifically in anterograde dilatation as described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VIP is crucial for the anterograde dilatation of the small intestine, promoting the relaxation of the intestinal segment ahead of the bolus during peristalsis, thereby facilitating the forward movement of intestinal contents.

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules are a feature of which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are melanocytic hamartomas found on the iris and are a hallmark of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are usually benign and do not affect vision. However, their presence is a key diagnostic criterion for NF1. Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas), cafe-au-lait macules (light brown skin spots), and skin fold freckling. Another significant feature is plexiform neurofibroma, which can present congenitally.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This is incorrect. Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by different skin lesions such as hypomelanotic macules (ash leaf spots), facial angiofibromas, and Shagreen patches. Lisch nodules are not associated with this condition.

 

Option C. Leprosy: This is incorrect. Leprosy (Hansen's disease) primarily affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes, but it does not involve the development of Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: This is incorrect. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, often affecting the lungs and lymph nodes, but not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented iris hamartomas specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and are an important diagnostic feature of this condition.

choices.text: Found in monovalent & pentavalent variant
Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding rotavirus vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months

 

Rotavirus vaccines are live, attenuated vaccines administered orally to protect against rotavirus infections, which can cause severe diarrhea in infants and young children. The vaccine is available in both monovalent and pentavalent forms.

 

The statement "Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months" is incorrect. The catch-up schedule for the rotavirus vaccine allows for administration up to one year of age. The vaccination schedule generally involves doses at 2 and 4 months of age, with a possible third dose at 6 months depending on the vaccine used. However, the vaccine series should ideally be completed by 8 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Live vaccine: This is true. The rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine.

 

Option B. Given orally: This is true. The rotavirus vaccine is administered orally, not by injection.

 

Option C. Found in monovalent & pentavalent variant: This is true. The vaccine is available in both monovalent and pentavalent forms, targeting different strains of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:


The catch-up schedule for the rotavirus vaccine extends up to one year of age, contrary to the incorrect statement that it should not be given after 6 months.

choices.text: Painless vaginal bleeding
Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding

questions.text: Antepartum hemorrhage due to abruption shows all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Painless vaginal bleeding

 

Explanation:

 

  • Painless vaginal bleeding is not a feature of abruption of the placenta. It is a characteristic feature of placenta previa.
  • Patients with placental abruption present with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.
  • Abruptio placenta is the partial or total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery, leading to bleeding and other complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Uterine tenderness: This is a common feature of placental abruption due to the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.

 

Option B. Frequent contractions: Increased frequency of uterine contractions is associated with placental abruption.

 

Option D. Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding: Vaginal bleeding of varying degrees, from mild to severe, is typically seen in placental abruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placental abruption presents with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions, but not with painless vaginal bleeding, which is characteristic of placenta previa.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg1944,  Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 297

choices.text: From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the tragus to the xiphisternum.
From the ala of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the ear lobule to the umbilicus

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

 

This is the correct method. The nasogastric tube length is usually measured by estimating the distance from the tip of the nose, past the ear lobule (or the earlobe), and down to the xiphisternum (the point where the sternum meets the costal margin), also known as N-E-X rule. This method ensures that the tube is long enough to pass through the esophagus and reach the stomach without being too long to cause complications or too short to not be effective.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

 

The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine examination

 

Based on the clinical presentation, it appears that congenital cytomegalovirus infection is a likely diagnosis. The most effective method for diagnosing the specific cause of the infection is by examining urine samples. In order to diagnose congenital CMV infection, the best specimens to use for culture are urine and saliva, while the best specimens for PCR testing are saliva and cord blood.

 

Clinical features:

 

  1. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
  2. Prematurity
  3. Hepatosplenomegaly
  4. Jaundice
  5. Blueberry-muffin-like rash
  6. Thrombocytopenia, purpura
  7. Microcephaly,
  8. Intracranial calcifications
  9. Chorioretinitis
  10. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  11. Mild increases in CSF protein.

 

Rx: Ganciclovir can limit hearing loss and improve the developmental outcome in symptomatically infected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. liver biopsy: liver biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option C. Blood examination: Blood examination will not give us the diagnostic results.

 

Option D. CSF examination: CSF examination is useful in cases of meningitis or neonatal sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine examination is the preferred diagnostic method for identifying congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which typically presents with symptoms such as intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications.

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given ultrasound image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phrygian cap

 

Phrygian caps are the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder. It denotes folding of the fundus back upon the gallbladder body and is asymptomatic with no pathological significance.

 

It is a normal anatomical variant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercedes-Benz sign: This sign is typically associated with pneumobilia, or air within the biliary tree, often seen in cases of fistula between the intestine and bile ducts or after certain surgical procedures. It is characterized by radiolucent branching structures that resemble the Mercedes-Benz logo, which is not evident in this ultrasound image.

 

Option B. Gall bladder polyp: Polyps would appear as echogenic masses attached to the gallbladder wall. They are usually well-defined and can vary in size. The image does not display any such formations.

 

Option C. Gall bladder cancer: This would generally appear as irregular, often thickened masses within the gallbladder, potentially with more heterogeneous echotexture compared to the surrounding liver tissue. This ultrasound does not show features typical of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Phrygian cap is the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder, appearing as a fold at the gallbladder fundus. It is asymptomatic and has no pathological significance, important to recognize in imaging to differentiate it from potential abnormalities.

questions.text: A 20-year-old sexual assault victim was examined in court "in camera." What does it imply? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed proceeding

 

"In camera" is a legal term used to describe a judicial proceeding that is held privately, away from the public and the media. This setting is particularly used in sensitive cases, such as those involving sexual assault, to protect the privacy and dignity of the victim. In such proceedings, only selected individuals, such as the judge, lawyers, the accused, the victim, and sometimes a few relatives of the victim, are allowed to be present.

 

This type of trial is mandated in India for all sexual assault cases to ensure the victim's confidentiality and provide a safe environment free from public scrutiny. It is not a public trial, and the general public is not allowed to attend.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open proceeding: An open proceeding is accessible to the public and media, which is not suitable for sensitive cases like sexual assault due to privacy concerns. This option is incorrect because "in camera" specifically denotes a closed proceeding.

 

Option C. Recorded in camera: This option might seem correct due to the term "camera," but it does not mean the proceedings are being recorded. "In camera" refers to the closed nature of the trial, not to any form of recording.

 

Option D. Proceedings in another place: This option incorrectly implies that the trial is conducted at a different location. However, "in camera" refers to the nature of the trial being private, not about the location of the proceedings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"In camera" refers to a closed proceeding in court where only selected individuals are allowed to be present, ensuring the privacy of sensitive cases such as those involving sexual assault.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The patient's clinical features are strongly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45XO), a condition characterized by:

 

  • Widely spaced nipples: Shield chest appearance.
  • Webbed neck: Due to congenital lymphedema.
  • Tanner grade 1 breast development: Indicates no breast development.
  • Streak ovaries on ultrasound: Ovaries that are underdeveloped and nonfunctional.
  • Hormonal profile: Raised FSH and LH due to lack of negative feedback from the ovaries, and reduced estradiol indicating ovarian failure.

 

Other clinical features of Turner syndrome include short stature, primary amenorrhea, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies. The syndrome results in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallmann syndrome: It is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), not hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: 46XY karyotype with female external genitalia, well-developed breasts, absent axillary and pubic hair, and gonads are testes, not streak ovaries.

 

Option D. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome: Mullerian agenesis, where secondary sexual characters are present but the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina are absent. This syndrome does not present with webbed neck or widely spaced nipples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, widely spaced nipples, and a webbed neck.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 441

questions.text: A patient presents with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs. To correct that, he tilts the head on one shoulder. Which nerve palsy is suspected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4th CN palsy

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presenting with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs and tilting the head on one shoulder to correct the vision suggests a 4th cranial nerve (CN) palsy. The 4th cranial nerve, also known as the trochlear nerve, innervates the superior oblique muscle.

 

The primary actions of the superior oblique muscle include intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye.

 

When there is a palsy of the 4th cranial nerve, the affected eye may have difficulty performing these movements, leading to vertical diplopia. Patients often adopt a compensatory head tilt to align the eyes properly and alleviate the double vision. The head tilt is typically towards the shoulder opposite the affected eye, compensating for the muscle's inability to properly intort and depress the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd CN palsy: This palsy typically presents with ptosis (drooping eyelid) and an eye that is deviated down and out. Patients often lift their chin to see beneath the drooping lid, not to correct vertical diplopia.

 

Option C. 6th CN palsy: The 6th cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for abduction of the eye. A palsy here would result in horizontal diplopia, not vertical diplopia, and the patient might turn their head to compensate, not tilt it.

 

Option D. 7th CN palsy: This nerve controls facial muscles, and its palsy leads to facial muscle weakness or paralysis, not issues related to eye movement or diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

4th cranial nerve palsy (trochlear nerve palsy) leads to vertical diplopia, which patients often compensate for by tilting their head to the opposite shoulder to align the eyes and improve vision.

 

Mnemonic – SO4 LR6 and rest all by cranial nerve 3

 

Superior oblique by 4th CN; Lateral rectus by 6th CN and Rest all muscle by 3rd CN
